column12: WOVEN FABRIC WITH HOLLOW CHANNEL FOR PREVENTION OF STRUCTURAL DAMAGE TO FUNCTIONAL YARN, MONOFILAMENT YARN, OR WIRE CONTAINED THEREIN
column13: A fabric substrate (100) having a warp direction (W) and a fill direction (F) is provided. The fabric substrate includes a plurality of warp yarns (112, 114) and a plurality of fill yarns (106). A portion of the plurality of the fill yarns (106) form a hollow channel (110) extending in the fill direction, and the hollow channel contains an encased fill yarn (108). As such, the encased fill yarn is protected from abrasion, bending, flexing, folding, compression, shrinkage, or expansion of the fabric substrate and remains undamaged after the fabric substrate is woven and subsequently handled or processed. In other embodiments, a hollow channel containing an encased yarn is formed in the warp direction, or hollow channels each containing an encased yarn are formed in both the fill direction and the warp direction.

column12: METHOD FOR SATELLITE BEACON SIGNAL DETECTION AND ANTENNA ALIGNMENT
column13: A method for detecting a beacon signal, by receiving a beacon signal and processing the beacon signal with respect to a local copy of the beacon signal. The processing including multiplying the beacon signal with a local copy of the beacon signal and integrating the result to generate a background noise filtered beacon signal output. The beacon signal output may be utilized to align an antenna with the beacon signal by adjusting alignment until the beacon signal output is either maximized or minimized, depending upon the function applied.

column12: Adjustable bedliner ballast system for vehicles
column13: The present invention is drawn to a bedliner ballast system for pick-up trucks, vans and other vehicles to allow the operators of vehicles to increase traction on the driving wheels by adding and removing weight to the bed of their vehicle and therefore adjusting the traction of the driving wheels without sacrificing load carrying space. The design permits the owner to easily and quickly add or remove weight as needed by using a liquid contained within the bed liner. Liquid may be added to directly weight, for example, the rear wheels with a garden hose or water faucet at a filling station while preserving the entire rear bed for passengers or freight and the additional load may be easily and quickly removed. The design permits custom modification for a variety of vehicles and vehicle configurations.

column12: Improvements in and relating to the Production of Healds for use in Looms and in the Apparatus or Appliances used therein.
column13: 11,168. Dean, T. E. May 16. Varnishing.-In apparatus for varnishing or sizing healds, shaft of healds d, e are mounted in a reciprocating frame b. As the frame moves to the right the healds e are supplied with varnish in the form of sprays or jets, as they pass between a funnel m<1>, and spraying or like devices l, l<1>, which are operated by compressed air. The healds then pass between revolving brushes f, g, which rub and consolidate the varnish. The brushes f, g are reciprocated vertically by a crank on a shaft h. When the healds have passed the devices l, l<1>, a stop o acts through levers p, q to draw a handle n to the right, and through arms n<1> to shut off the supply of varnish and compressed air from the spraying-devices l, l<1>. A stop u<1> effects the reverent of the motion of the frame by acting on ordinary gearing v. The healds d are then similarly treated. The handles n are moved by hand to admit varnish and compressed air to the spraying-devices. Auxiliary smootbing-brushes f<1> may act on the healds. These brushes consist of endless bands with their outer faces formed as brushes. Each band passes over three revolving pulleys y<1>, so arranged that the part of the brush acting on the healds is parallel thereto. The pulleys are mounted in a swinging frame which is acted on by a cam on the handle n, so that the brush f<1> is in action only during the varnishing operation. In another form of machine, the shafts of healds are mounted between two adjustable endless bands passing continuously over pulleys. Spraying-devices are mounted in advance of each set of brushes used. The bands may be moved intermittently to give greater time for each operation. The healds may be stationary, and the brushes and spraying-devices may be moved, the necessary flexible connections being provided. The spray may be applied either by hand before or during the brushing operation. The spraying and brushing operations may also be effected in different machines. The varnish may be applied to both sides of the healds, or may be sprayed upon the brushes by which it is applied to the healds.

column12: GAS-LEAK DETECTOR.
Reversible displacement pumps
column13: A pump has a cylindrical casing, a discoid rotor in the casing having arms each extending in an axial direction from the rotor and sliding over the inner surface of the casing upon rotor rotation, each arm having a flap pivoted at one end to that arm and having its other end slidably engaging a curved surface of an adjacent arm. An inner member freely rotates over an eccentric shaft and is coupled by links to the flaps so that, upon rotation, the flaps pivot towards and away from the casing to effect pumping action. Each arm, flap, link, and the inner member is of constant cross-sectional shape, so that production costs are low.

The layers (30,32,34) include at least an inner layer (30), an outer layer (34) and a fuel permeation barrier layer (32) disposed between the inner layer (30) and the outer layer (34) and being made of a nanocomposite polymer.

column12: Body restraint
column13: A restraint for holding a person in a side-lying position on a bed and comprising a flexible main section with one or more arm members extending therefrom and further including fastening straps for engaging the bed. The restraint is adapted so as to be quickly and easily attached to and removed from a person being restrained in the side-lying position so as to accommodate usage by a singular health care provider.

column12: Shock absorbing assembly for a hydraulic catwalk
column13: A shock absorbing assembly ( 10 ) has a front plate ( 12 ) and a rear plate ( 14 ) separated by spacers ( 16 ). The plates and the spacers each have holes ( 18 A, 18 B), the upper holes ( 18 A) in the front plate preferably being threaded. Fasteners, such as but not limited to threaded rods ( 22 A, 22 B) and locknuts ( 24 A, 24 B), hold the spacers in position between the front plate and the rear plate. The threaded rods ( 22 A) are screwed into the threaded holes in the front plate but do not protrude from the front face of the front plate. The threaded rods ( 22 A) are secured by locknuts 24 A on one end and the threaded rods ( 22 B) are secured by locknuts 24 B on both ends. The rear plate also has a pair of engagement plates ( 20 ) which position the assembly on the catwalk.

column12: Polymer nanocomposite and process for making the same
column13: Disclosed herein is a method for producing a nanocomposite, comprising exfoliating a nanofiller in a first polymer to form a precursor, combining the precursor with a second polymer to exfoliate the nanofiller in the second polymer; and wherein the second polymer is miscible with the first polymer and less than about 10 wt % of the nanofiller exfoliates when mixed directly with the second polymer, and greater than or equal to about 10 wt % of the nanofiller exfoliates in the nanocomposite when the precursor and second polymer are combined. Further disclosed herein is a nanocomposite comprising a first polymer having a nanofiller exfoliated in the first polymer, a second polymer, and wherein the second polymer is miscible with the first polymer and less than about 10 wt % of the nanofiller exfoliates when mixed directly with the second polymer, and greater than or equal to about 10 wt % the nanofiller exfoliates in the nanocomposite when the precursor and second polymer are combined.

column12: GAME BOARD APPARATUS
column13: A game board apparatus exhibiting a playing field for supporting thereupon a movable object introduced at a launch area located at one end of the playing field. A target area is positioned at a further location of the playing field for receiving the object. One or more obstacles are further located between the launch and target area and which are configured to modify a direction of travel of the object, such as to eliminate any linear path from the launch area to the target area, thus necessitating that the objects instead move along paths dictated by the obstacle(s) in order to reach the target area from the launch area.

column12: ADAPTIVE METHOD AND SYSTEM FOR ENCODING DIGITAL IMAGES FOR THE INTERNET
column13: A system and method comprise defining a current rectangular region of the image bitmap, quantifying spectral characteristics of the current rectangular region, dividing the current rectangular region into four rectangular sub-regions in response to the spectral characteristics being greater than a predetermined threshold value, tagging the current rectangular sub-region as a terminal rectangular region in response to the spectral characteristics being less than or equal to the predetermined threshold value, tagging each rectangular sub-region as a terminal rectangular region in response to a size of the rectangular sub-region being less than or equal to a predetermined threshold size, defining one of the non-terminal rectangular sub-regions as the current rectangular region and repeating the above until all rectangular regions are tagged terminal, and determining color characteristics for each of the terminal rectangular regions.

Class 47 A fire extinguisher comprises a container 1 maintained under internal pressure and provided with a frangible sealing disc 4 to be ruptured by a piercer 9 to release the contents, the sealing disc 4 being enclosed by a cover 1 held against accidental removal from the container and constituting an outlet chamber closed except for an outlet 12 through which the contents of the container 1 are discharged, and the cover being mounted to slide with straight line movement and carrying the piercer 9, whereby the disc 4 can be ruptured by a blow on the cover 1. column12: Transparent thermoplastic composition
column13: 863,279. Transparent thermoplastic compositions. DISTILLERS CO. Ltd. May 1, 1959 [May 15, 1958], No. 15589/58. Class 2(6). Transparent thermoplastic compositions comprise 1-15% of a synthetic rubber which is of refractive index 1À533-1À563 and is a polymer or copolymer of a conjugated diene in a copolymer of 30-75% of styrene with methyl methacrylate. The conjugated diene from which the synthetic rubber is prepared may be butadiene, isoprene, chloroprene or dimethylbutadiene. The synthetic rubber is exemplified by copolymers of butadiene and styrene. The synthetic rubber may be mixed with the styrene-methyl methacrylate copolymer on a calender or in a rotary mill or the synthetic rubber may be dissolved and the solution mixed with the styrene-methyl methacrylate copolymer or a solution thereof; alternatively, the synthetic rubber may be present in the monomer mixture from which the styrenemethyl methacrylate copolymer is made. The styrene-methyl methacrylate copolymer may be made by copolymerizing a mixture of the monomers in the absence of a polymerization initiator, the polymerization being initiated at above 100‹C. Light and heat stabilizers and plasticizers and lubricants such as paraffin hydrocarbons and butyl stearate may be incorporated.

column12: MOP.
Method of forming a fabric containing a functional code pattern
column13: A method of producing a textile product wherein a functional code pattern is structurally embedded within a textile product as the textile yarns are interlaced to become a textile product is provided. The functional code pattern is embedded within the textile product by programming a textile process machine with conversion factors and mathematical ratios, producing an enlarged code pattern that adheres to the customary rules of public or proprietary barcode formatting. Alternatively, the functional code pattern can be digitally printed onto the textile. The resulting textile product includes a functional and decorative code pattern that is readable by a standard electronic code reading device. Depending upon the type of textile yarn materials used, the code pattern created in or printed on the textile fabric may or may not be visible to the human eye.

Power tool system, charger, power tool and voice control method therefor, and automatic working system, charging station, automatic moving device and voice control method therefor
column13: A power tool system (100), which comprises a power tool (3, 4) and a charger (1), and a voice control method for a power tool system is disclosed. The power tool system comprises: a voice acquisitioncomponent (101) for acquiring voice information from a user; and a control module for acquiring instruction information generated based on the voice information and controlling, based on the instruction information, the power tool system so same executes a corresponding action; and the power tool system comprises: a voice processing component (102), which is at least used for generating information which corresponds ng to the voice information and conforms to a communication component transmission format; and a communication component (103) for sending the information processed by the voice processing component to a server and receiving corresponding information from the server, and providing response information to the control module, wherein the instruction information comprises the response information. Also disclosed are an automatic working system, which comprises an automatic moving device and a charging station, and a voice control method for an automatic working system. The automatic working system comprises: a voice acquisition component, a control module, a voice processing component, and a communication component. The present invention has the beneficial effect of a userbeing able to directly send a request by means of voice information to conveniently obtain various pieces of required information and implement various types of control, such that a power tool systembecomes a "personal working site assistant" of the user, and the functions of the power tool system are expanded.

Improvements in and relating to Centrifugal Separators.
column13: 102,284. Brown, T. E. Jan. 26, 1916. Strainer separators; baskets or drums; driving; charging and feeding; discharging.-The separator drum is provided with a movable top and a reciprocating piston for the ejection of deposits without stopping the machine, and the valves controlling the feed of the material to be treated, and the movement of the deposit-discharging devices, may be automatically operated. The invention is illustrated in two forms in Figs. 1 and 2. In that shown in Fig. 1, the drum 14 is carried by a frame 13 on a hollow shaft 9 and has an axially movable top 20 connected to a piston-like bottom plate 17 by webs 19. The filtering-material 21 is positioned transversely in the top 20 between perforated plates, the outlets for the liquid being pipes 23. Material to be treated is fed in by the pipe 29, and when sufficient deposit has accumulated in the drum, the parts 17, 20 are raised, and the part 17 forces the deposit out into the trough 42. The parts 17, 20 are raised and lowered by a piston 15 working in a cylinder 10. This cylinder 10 connects the part 9 of the main shaft with the part 8, with which it rotates, and is supplied on the upper side of the piston 15 with fluid led in through the hollow piston-rod 16, and on the underside, with fluid led in by the central pipe 18. All these parts rotate, and the pressure on the niston is due to the centrifugal force in the fluid. Spill-holes 45 and a leakage hole 50 are provided in the cylinder. While separation is proceeding, the top 20 is held tightly against a leakage-preventing ring 24, and the plate 17 is packed at the periphery by a fluidpressed ring 27. The trough 42 for the solids is preferably mounted to rotate, so that the solids may be removed from it by a scraper 51. The separated liquid is caught in a trough 41, from which it is led by a pipe 46 to a trough 43, and thence out of the machine. Bearings 3, 4, 5 are provided for the shaft. The liquid for actuating the piston 15 is supplied by pipes 31, 32 connected as shown, and having regulating-valves 33, 34. The machine may be made automatic in operation by opening and closing the pipes 29, 31, 32 automatically at suitable times. This may be effected by valves 38, 39, 40 controlled electrically. The switch 61 has strips 66, 67, 68 wired to the valve solenoids as shown, and a contact-arm 65 carried by a shaft 60 rotated at constant speed by clock-work or other means. In the modification shown in Fig. 2, the top 98 and bottom 96 of the centrifugal drum are moved by a piston 95 in a cylinder 91, which is supplied with fluid under pressure from a pipe 73 by connexions 84, 74. The cylinder 91 also acts as,belt pulley for the main drive. The pipes 73, 74 and the feed-pipe 75 have regulating-valves 78, 79, 81, and the machine may be made automatic by providing valves 82, 83 controlled electrically by a switch 114, the arm 118 of which is rotated at constant speed by a motor 117 through gearing 116, 115. The filtering-medium, in this modification, comprises a coarse screen 103, a fine screen 105, and intermediate granular filtering- material 104, such as sand. One or both screens 103. 105 may be omitted if the granular filter will stay in place. The material 104 may be supplied and packed by centrifugal force while the machine is running, by closing the valve 81 and opening the valve 80 in the sand and water pipe. The outer layer of the filter may be charcoal For removing the filter 104, the plate 109 on the drum is detachable. The trough 110 for the discharged solids rotates, a fixed scraper 111 being provided.

column12: Improvements in or relating to direction indicators for vehicles
column13: 773,591. Road-traffic signals on vehicles. VULGARIAN ENGINEERS, Ltd. Feb. 22, 1955 [Feb. 22, 1954], No. 5207/54. Class 118 (2). A direction indicator suitable for a pedal cycle comprises a rigid strip of metal forming a closed loop, and an indicating member pivotally mounted in the loop so as to swing on either side thereof, which loop and indicating member are provided with corresponding contours so that the latter may lie snugly within the former. The ends 12, 13 of a metal strip bent into a loop having the same shape as that of a translucent indicator 11 overlap one another and accommodate an adjustable socket 14 for a control cable 15. The indicator 11 is pivoted between a pin 43 provided in the bottom part of the metal loop frame and on an adjustable threaded plug 28 in the upper part of the frame. The plug 28 has a conical end engaging a conical recess 32 in the metal plate 30 closing the top of translucent trough-shaped member 11. The control cable 15 passes round and is secured to a pulley 46 carried by pivot pin 43. A pin 48 extends from pulley 46 to engage a hole in the bottom of indicator 11. The loop frame is provided with curved clip members 61 and 62 for securing it to the rear mudguard of the cycle. The cable 15 also passes around another pulley inside a casing 52 having a clip 53 for attachment to the handle-bars of the cycle. This pulley is rotatable by means of a lever 58. A battery 26 is carried on top of the loop frame and is connected to a contact pin 25 which extends through the hollow centre of plug 28 to the inside of indicator 11. The end of contact pin 25 is flattened at 33 and lies between the arms of a springy metal fork member 34 which is connected to one side of a lamp 40 carried within indicator 11. When the indicator arm 11 is swung to either side of the loop frame by operation of lever 58 contact between the fork member 34 and flat end 33 of contact pin 25 causes lamp 40 to light up, the return circuit being through the metal plate 30 and the frame of the device. The loop frame may also carry the normal rear lamp and reflector.

Drawer and insert for rapid removal of valuables
column13: A system providing rapid and efficient evacuation of valuables from a storage site such a home or office. Such rapid evacuation is often required in the face of impending disaster. A storage container, for example a drawer, is provided with an inner lining. Valuables are stored on the lining within the drawer. The lining itself is an open carrier having side walls which are folded so as to configure the liner to the drawer. In the case of emergency evacuation, the side walls of the liner are rapidly unfolded by grasping draw strings which act to remove the liner from the drawer and to close the liner to provide a closed transport carrier for the valuables stored within the drawer.

Improvements in Locks.
column13: 14,721. Ellis, W. T. July 19. Locks, key; escutcheons, keyhole.-The first part of the invention relates to a padlock. The bow H is connected at one end by a link to a pivoted disc B, and at the other end it has a slotted hole adapted to receive a pin P passing through a hole in the casing. The disc B is provided with indents x, y adapted to be engaged by a spring-controlled pawl F. When locked, the pawl engages the indent x, and the pin P engages the holes in the bow and casing. In unlocking, the pawl F is moved out of engagement with the disc, by means of a key E, and is afterwards released, the bow is then pulled out, thereby turning the disc until the pawl engages the indent y. In this position the slots in the hole in the bow and in the holes in the casing are brought into line so as to allow a projection on the pin P to pass. The pin can now be withdrawn, until it engages the slot in the front plate, and the bow H is free. The locking is performed by a reverse operation. The second part of the invention relates to a keyhole guard and a blocking-device for the mechanism, and is applicable to any lock. A keyhole cover A, provided with a long and a short recess, is adapted to slide on a dovetailed projection on the front plate of the lock. A spring-controlled sliding piece K, mounted on the back of the front plate, has a projecting part passing through the plate and, normally, engaging the short recess. A piece W, prevented from rotation by contact with a stop, forms a nut for the engagement of a screw R, passing through the front plate. This piece W may be moved by rotating the screw so as to bring it in position for locking some part of the lock mechanism, such as the pawl F. In operation, the cover A is raised to expose the keyhole. The key is inserted and turned to pass the end of a pivoted lever L. The key is then turned to depress the lever L, which engages the piece K and slides it forward into engagement with the long recess in the cover A. The cover is forced downwards, after the withdrawal of the key, and the head of the screw is exposed. The screw may now be operated to release the piece W from engagement with the lock mechanism. By reversing the operations, the mechanism may again be blocked.

column12: Rodent trap
column13: A rodent trap 100 comprising a gangway 114 moveably mounted within a housing 105 having an entrance 106 and an exit 112. An entrance end region is positioned toward the entrance of the housing and an exit end region is positioned toward the exit of the housing. The gangway is arranged to rest in a first position allowing an animal access into the entrance of the housing and is further arranged such that the weight of an animal moving from the entrance end region to the exit end region causes it to move to a second position such that the animal can leave the gangway and move toward the exit of the trap. The gangway is further arranged such that when in the first position an animal is prevented from moving from the exit of the housing to the entrance of the housing. The trap may further comprise a funnel 120 with an entry end 122 larger than its exit end 124. The trap may further comprise a holding pen (200, fig 2) arranged to receive an animal emerging from the exit.

column12: TIME SWITCHES

This allows a user to observe in real-time the position of the self-propelled mobile apparatus (10) via the control terminal, and improves the safeness of the self-propelled mobile apparatus (10).

column13: 1,129,263. Timeswitches. SANGAMO WESTON Ltd. 27 Oct., 1965 [29 Oct., 1964], No. 44204/64. Heading H1N. A micro-switch 52 is moved "on" and "off" at selected times as the result of the temporary coupling of one or other of two constantlyrotating pawls with one or other of two toothed wheels. The "on" pawl 66 rotates with a motordriven member 15 (Fig. 2, not shown) and co-operates with pins 24a insertable, in selected holes in a fixed plate 12. When the pawl engages a pin 24a, the pawl is rocked about its pivot 64 to engage a tooth 69 with a toothed wheel 44 loosely carried by the member 15. The wheel 44 is thus rotated through a limited angle and a pin 45 thereon moves a switch actuating lever 47 to close the switch, the wheel being returned by a spring 49 (Fig. 2, not shown) when the pawl has moved past the pin 24a. The switch is held closed by a lever 57 which latches lever 47 until lever 57 is subsequently moved clockwise against spring action by a pin on the second toothed wheel 57 (Fig. 2, not shown) when this is engaged by the second pawl 65 (Fig. 2, not shown) at a time corresponding to a second pin similar to 24a, A rotary knob carries a member 39 which can be moved either way to engage lever 47 or latch 57 to provide a manual override, an indicator lamp being contained within the knob. The member 15 is set by hand to indicate the actual setting time and is. specially shaped so that it can only be rotated clockwise.

column12: METHOD OF FORMING A FABRIC CONTAINING A FUNCTIONAL CODE PATTERN
column13: A method of producing a textile product wherein a functional code pattern is structurally embedded within a textile product as the textile yarns are interlaced to become a textile product is provided. The functional code pattern is embedded within the textile product by programming a textile process machine with conversion factors and mathematical ratios, producing an enlarged code pattern that adheres to the customary rules of public or proprietary barcode formatting. Alternatively, the functional code pattern can be digitally printed onto the textile. The resulting textile product includes a functional and decorative code pattern that is readable by a standard electronic code reading device. Depending upon the type of textile yarn materials used, the code pattern created in or printed on the textile fabric may or may not be visible to the human eye.

column12: Woven Fabric with Hollow Channel for Prevention of Structural Damage to Functional Yarn, Monofilament Yarn, or Wire Contained Therein
column13: A fabric substrate having a warp direction and a fill direction is provided. The fabric substrate includes a plurality of warp yarns, a plurality of fill yarns. A portion of the plurality of the fill yarns form a hollow channel extending in the fill direction, and the hollow channel contains an encased fill yarn. As such, the encased fill yarn is protected from abrasion, bending, flexing, folding, compression, shrinkage, or expansion of the fabric substrate and remains undamaged after the fabric substrate is woven and subsequently handled or processed. In other embodiments, a hollow channel containing an encased yarn is formed in the warp direction, or hollow channels each containing an encased yarn are formed in both the fill direction and the warp direction.

column13: An electric tool system, including an electric tool and a charger. The electric tool system includes: a voice obtaining component, obtaining voice information from a user; and a control module, obtaining instruction information generated based on the voice information, and controlling the electric tool system based on the instruction information to perform a corresponding action, where the electric tool system includes: a voice processing component, at least configured to generate information that corresponds to the voice information and satisfies a transmission format of a communications component; and the communications component, sending the information processed by the voice processing component to a server, receiving response information from the server, and providing the response information to the control module, where the instruction information includes the response information. The beneficial effects of the present invention are as follows: A user may directly send a request by using voice information, thereby conveniently obtaining various required information or implementing various controls, so that an electric tool system becomes a “personal worksite assistant” of the user, thereby extending the functions of the electric tool system.

column12: Cable termination to connector allowing relative movement
column13: In an electrical connector a first tube 10 is secured to a mating portion 11 by means of a retaining nut 12 gripping a flanged portion 14 against a complementary part 15 of the mating portion 11. A second tube 16 is secured to a cable 17 through the agency of a ferrule 18. Cable conductors 19 are brought to terminations 100 within the second tube 16 to which flexible conductors 101 are also attached to form a path onward to mating portion 11. The first tube 10 and second tube 11 are nested one in the other such that they are relatively rotatable. Substantially lengthwise relative movement is prevented by pins 102, 103 protruding from the ferrule 18 and through a slot in the first tube 10, such that relative rotational movement is limited. The invention overcomes the problem of providing strain free connection of semi-rigid cables, the precise mating orientation of which is uncertain following installation. <IMAGE>

Tamper-resistant fastener key
column13: A key for a tamper-resistant fastener having three sockets, one below the other, one of the sockets being eccentric relative to the center axis of the fastener. The key comprises a flat blade portion having integral upper, middle and lower insertable portions, the center axis of the middle insertable portion being off-set from the center axis of the key. The width and length of each of the insertable portions corresponds respectively to the diameter and depth of the upper, middle, and lower sockets. The upper and lower insertable portions of the key prevent tilting of the key when torque is applied by the off-centered middle section to the eccentric middle socket of the fastener.

Woven fabric substrate for prevention of structural damage to functional yarns contained therein
column13: A fabric substrate material is provided. The fabric substrate includes at least a first layer and a second layer. The first layer includes a first plurality of non-functional fill yarns and at least one functional fill yarn, and the second layer includes a second plurality of fill yarns. The second plurality of fill yarns and the at least one functional fill yarn exhibit substantially the same compressive strength, compressive resistance, or flexural strength. As such, the functional fill yarn in the first layer is protected from shrinkage or expansion and remains undamaged and functional after the fabric substrate is woven and subsequently handled or processed. The aforementioned practice of reinforcement described in the fill direction of the second layer can also be applied in the warp yarn direction, using the same principles described herein.

column12: Cable retention unit
column13: A cable retention unit is designed to assist in the prevention of cable theft from the rail industry and to assist in improving the cable maintenance activity. The cable retention unit formed from a pair of rubber faced plates between which a cable may be positioned. The rubber faced plates grip and hold the outer surface of the cable and preventing the cable from being pulled out of the retention unit in a direction along which the cable lies in the trunk. Cables are placed into, and removed from, the retention unit in a direction orthogonal to the direction along which the cable lies. A side trap is also located at each end to prevent the cable moving in outward directions. The unit is covered by a security cover, which once removed gives access to the cable inside. The unit can hold up to 3 cables of either the same or differing sizes.

column12: METHOD AND APPARTUS FOR ALTERING PHASE SHIFT ALONG A TRANSMISSION LINE SECTION
column13: A new technique is presented that allows for controlling the phase of a propagating signal by selectively switching in and out relatively small perturbations along a transmission line section that provide slightly different physical paths for the currents to follow. By using relatively minor perturbations, the phase of a transmission line section can be controlled without drastically altering the impedance of the section, thereby maintaining good impedance matching properties. Also, by keeping the alternate current paths small, generally fine control of phase shift is possible along with allowing the design to remain relatively simple. Such tunable elements can then be incorporated in designs where resonators (or other elements) are separated by specific phase lengths to construct other signal processing functions, such as filters.

column13: 12,046. Ellis, J. T. May 15. Motor road vehicles.-Relates to velocipedes and motor cycles. The handle-bar is made so that it can be laid parallel with the frame. The Specification describes a number of modified forms of the means for connecting the handle-bar to the stem to facilitate this movement. In Fig. 4, B<1> represents the stem and B a collar secured thereto. The top of the stem B' is squared and a seat on the handle-bar A<1> fits thereon. The handle-bar A' is adjustably secured by clips A, A, one of which carries a screw b<13> with locking-nut b<14> to engage a recess in the bracket B, while the other clip A carries a screw working in a block b<10> pivoted at b<12> to the bracket B. In order that the brake lever may turn with the handle-bar, it is connected to the brake stem by an intermediate piece connected to both the said lever and said stem by pin joints. The brake may be held against the wheel by an eccentric cam piece or its equivalent attached to the brake stem and adapted to be turned so as to bear against some rigid part of the handle-bar stem or frame. The eccentric or its equivalent may be so slotted or shaped that it may engage with a correspondingly-shaped part of the steering-stem to form a steering-lock. Means for locking the wheels are also described. A tubular boss is applied to the hub or other outer bearing. A hollow threaded pin, having its end recessed for operation by a special key, works inside the boss, and its end is adapted to work through the oil-hole and bear against the shaft to prevent rotation. column13: 100,317. Brown, T. E. April 16, 1915, [Convention date]. Strainer separator.-In apparatus for the centrifugal separation of solids and liquids, the various steps in the process, such as filtration, drying and washing, and the final discharge of the concentrates, are performed without stopping the rotation of the machine bv employing separating - vessels adapted to be periodically reversed in position to permit the centrifugal discharge of the solids after separation, automatic or other timing-devices being provided to control the duration of the successive steps in the process. In one construction, four separating- vessels A, B, C, D and a cylinder 7 are mounted to rotate with a shaft 9 driven by a belt 12 and pulley 13. When the vessels A, B, C, D, which are mounted on individual spindles 1, are in the position shown by the dotted lines in Fig. 1, the piston 16 is at the top of the cylinder 7, and a pressure fluid is admitted through a pipe 28, the shaft 9, holes 38 in the sleeve 17, and ducts 39 in the piston 16 to the upper side of the piston, where, by its centrifugal pressure, it forces down the piston and by means of the sleeve 17 and head 18 presses down the rollers 19 and turns the vessels A, B, C, D into the position shown in full lines. The materials to be separated are then admitted by the valve 26 and pipe 25 into the spouts 21 and the separating-vessels, the liquid passing through the strainer and filter 22 on to shields 24 and trough 50. The valve 26 is then shut off, and after,a lapse of time sufficient to dry the solids accumulated on the filter 22, the operating-fluid is again admitted from the pipe 28 with such rapidity as to exceed the amount which can flow out through the leakage holes 41. The cylinder of liquid above the piston then extends inwardly until it passes through the holes 42 to the underside, balancing the pressure above, so that the centrifugal forces of the vessels A, 13, C, D are unbalanced, and the vessels turn on their spindles to the position shown in dotted lines, the contained solids being discharged centrifugally into a revolving trough 52. The vessels A, B, C, D are then restored to their original position by reducing the supply of operating-fluid, and the process is recommenced. The timing of the successive steps may be controlled automatically by a. contact-arm 43 rotating at a uniform speed over contact plates 45, 46, 47 connected with solenoids actuating valves. 33, 27, 34. In a modification, the separating-vessels are arranged to be turned on axes parallel to the spindle 9 by an oscillating- vane motor, and hydraulic instead of electric operation of the valves is employed, the timing being effected by a uniformly rotating valve controlling the distribution of the hydraulic pressure. One cr more washing stages may be introduced into the process. Upper and lower bearings 10, 11 are provided for the shaft 9, the weight of the machine being carried on a thrust bearing 14 supported on an oscillating frame 2, which, with the balls 3 and base-plate 4, forms a self-balancing device. The Specification as open to inspection under Sect. 91 (3) (a) states that imperforate vessels may be used with the apparatus described, the process being one of decantation instead of filtration. This subject-matter does not appear in the Specification as accepted.

column12: BASCULE-BRIDGE.

Screw/nut/bolt driver for pneumatic, impact, hand crank or other use having an insertable magnet in the head to hold/keep screw/nut/bolt or specialized tips attached to driver but inserted by screwing it in, as it is threaded and inside of driver head (below screw/nut/bolt receiving area), is identically threaded to receive it
column13: The unique aspect of this invention is the fact that the magnet insert screws into the driver shaft head rather than being pressed in under pressure. The best design for this invention includes self-locking threads as well and the combination of using a threaded installation of the magnet insert and the locking threads is an additional unique attribute to this invention. This unique a threaded install attribute helps prevent the magnet insert from coming out under impact pressure and even if it does it allows it to be reinserted using a screwing mechanism and when reinserted will remain in place unlike existing press-in products. A third unique attribute of this invention is the depression at the top of the magnet insert designed to receive a screwing tools such as a flat head or Philips screw driver, hex, Allen, etc., making it possible to easily reinsert the magnet insert and tighten it firmly in place.

column12: BASCULE-BRIDGE.
SYSTEM FOR DISINFECTING OBJECTS
column13: Disclosed is a system for disinfecting objects in an environment. The system includes a UV light source for disinfecting the objects in an environment, an attachment unit to attach the UV light source to a fixed support, and a switch to operate the UV light source. The switch is also an automatic timer programmed to perform for a pre-defined duration. Further, the system includes a cabinet for housing the UV light source, a sensor to automatically shut down the UV light when door of the cabinet opens and a platform to rotate the objects inside the cabinet. Further, the system may include a conveyor belt to carry the objects under the UV light.

column12: Position error signal (PES) detection
column13: Methods and apparatuses for modulating a position error signal detection gate signal responsive to a track crossing velocity are discussed. The position error signal can be used to detect position information. A track crossing velocity can be estimated and then used via the modulating. Phase errors due to the track crossing velocity can be minimized.

column12: Ride n' Grow Children's Bicycle System
column13: The present invention is in the technical field of sporting and recreation. More particularly, the present invention is in the technical field of children's bikes. Conventional children's bikes last only a short time because the children outgrow them and or no longer find the style of the bike appealing. It is costly and time consuming to keep up with a child's needs and also his ever-changing tastes in trends. The present invention is a complete response to this issue. The present invention is a bicycle with a frame that has been designed to allow all sizes of wheel diameters to work on the same bike. The tires can be changed and the look of the bicycle can also be changed. Thus as a child grows, the bike can grow with him.

column12: Silly Treadz, Wrolly Writers, Safety Treadz, and Re-Treadz: A Separate Tire and Tread System, Which Allows for the Replacement of the Tread for any Reason
column13: The present invention is a wheel, tire and tread system that is used to change wheel diameters, change treads for varying terrains, for safety reasons, to re-tread or to tread designs. The tread designs can be used to exhibit brands, prints, imprints and they can also be used as molds. The invention is comprised of a separate tread and a separate tire to be used together. It is also comprised of a key, distinguishing factor, which are the attachments that are located on the sidewalls of these tires. These attachments allow for the separate tread and the separate tire to be used together. The present invention is used by attaching the varying treads to the varying wheels through slipping the holes on the treads into the buttons on the wheels. The pieces fit together forming one unit and function as any typical tire should.

column12: ANTI-SINK INSTANT FLOTATION DEVICE FOR BOATS, SHIPS, BARGES, AIRPLANES, ETC.
column13: The greatest threat to any boat, ship, barge, airplane, etc. that is out upon the water is sinking. This process have has countless lives and trillions of dollars worth of lost materials and possessions over the millennia. This invention provides a device to be attached to a boat, ship, barge, airplane, etc. ahead of time that can be self-activating or can be activated manually, by a switch, that will deploy a gas-filled balloon that will prevent the boat, ship, barge, airplane, etc. from sinking.

column12: Knitting aid
Silly Solez
column13: The present invention is called Silly Solez. This device is a portion of the tread, sole, footwear top or footwear bottom which can easily be removed and then replaced. This device can be used on any type of footwear to print, imprint or mold with either side of the device. It can also be removed and used as a stamp. The present invention can be made with or without a resevoir to allow ink or dye to release and leave prints of the various designs. The present invention can also be used as a removable waterproof storage device on the top or the bottom of the sole of footwear.

column13: The present invention relates to biomaterials, in particular bacterial cellulose and provides means to prepare pigmented cellulose at acidic pH 5.8, wherein cellulose pellicles comprising tyrosinase (EC 1.14.18.1) are melanated using a development solution at pH 6 to 8.5 and comprises tyrosine, cysteine and/or cystine. Further, the invention relates to means of preparing spatially restricted pigmented cellulose using an optogenetic expression system wherein two polymerase or transcription factor domains are split and each linked to a light-inducible dimerization domain. The invention provides corresponding methods and components.

SELF-MOVING APPARATUS, CHARGING STATION, AUTOMATIC WORKING SYSTEM AND INSECT INHIBITION DEVICE
column13: The present invention relates to an insect suppression device, and further relates to a self-moving device, a charging station, and an automatic working system that are mounted with the insect suppression device. The self-moving device moves in a working area, performs a working task, and includes: a body and a movement module that is mounted on the body and drives the self-moving device to move. The self-moving device includes: an insect suppression device, mounted to the body, and a control module, controlling the movement module to move and controlling the insect suppression device to work. The beneficial effects of the present invention are as follows: The self-moving device can move autonomously in the working area and perform an insect suppression task, and has a wide coverage area, flexible work, and high efficiency, so that automatic control can be implemented, thereby freeing a user from the harassment of insects.

column12: Inlaid tile gutter system
column13: An inlaid tile gutter system for use in swimming pools contains a channel, braces mounted atop the primary gravity flow channel and stiffeners mounted on the poolside of the channel provide a relatively stiff gutter system capable of withstanding deformations due to excessive loadings and impact. Ferro concrete material may be placed within channels formed by the vertical stiffeners to provide a support and a base upon which to set tile.

SELF-MOVING APPARATUS, CHARGING STATION, AUTOMATIC WORKING SYSTEM AND INSECT INHIBITION DEVICE
column13: Disclosed are an insect inhibition device (10), a self-moving apparatus (1) having the insect inhibition device (10) installed thereon, a charging station (200), and an automatic working system (101). Disclosed is a self-moving apparatus (1) moving in a working area (300) and executing a work task. The self-moving apparatus (1) comprises: a main body (3); and a moving module (5) installed on the main body (3) and driving the self-moving apparatus (1) to move. The self-moving apparatus (1) also comprises: an insect inhibition device (10) installed on the main body (3); and a control module controlling the moving module (5) to move and controlling the work of the insect inhibition device (10). The self-moving apparatus (1) can autonomously move in the working area (300) and execute an insect inhibition task. The self-moving apparatus has a wide coverage, works flexibly and efficiently, and is capable of realizing automatic control to allow a user to get rid of the annoyance caused by insects.

column13: Disclosed is a power controller for supplying a load (120) from first and second power supplies. The power controller comprises a first storage means (315) arranged to store power from the first power supply and switching means (325,335) arranged to switch between a second storage means (330) and the first storage means (315) or the second power supply depending on a parameter of the first (315) and second (330) storage means. Improvements in Apparatus or Machines for Dipping Ceramic-ware and other like Ware into Liquid Glaze or Colour.
column13: 5090. Ellis, S. H., and Holt, T. Feb. 28. Enamelling.-Comprises improvements in the dipping-tub described in Specification 5673/00. To render the ware-holding cages adjustable for different sizes of ware, they are provided with uprights p which have inward projections z, Fig. 4, for supporting the ware and are attached to feet r adjustable in radial grooves in the base-plate q. One of the uprights is hinged at y so that it can be turned down for the introduction of the ware, and is secured by a fastening. The uprights are secured together at the top by a bolt x passing through slotted arms &c. w. The brackets h, Fig. 2, which carry the spindles g of disks f supporting the cages, are formed with bearings both at the top and bottom, and the driving-pinions are mounted at the bottom, as shown, to protect the brackets h and gearing j, k from the glaze, they are enclosed by a guard c suspended from the bracket 24. A charger is employed in conjunction with the cages for the introduction and withdrawal of the ware and comprises a frame 2, Fig. 7, provided with three uprights 3 having ware-supporting projections 4 similar to those of the cages; the hinged upright p of a cage having been turned down and the charger placed in front of the cage, the ware can be slidden from the charger to the cage or vice versa by tilting the cage and charger. Means are also provided for straining the glaze. A box 11, Fig. 3, provided with a sieve 14, is mounted upon flexible arms 12 and is vibrated by a crank pin 16 working in a slotted plate secured to one of the arms. Glaze is withdrawn from the bottom of the tub a through a pipe 10 by a suitable pump and is delivered into the box 11, the sifted glaze passing into a trough 19 and back into the tub through an opening 20.

column12: Captive screw with one direction ratchet
column13: A captive screw assembly 10 is attached to a panel 80, and comprises a screw 30 hand tightenable by means of a knob 20 connected by a one-direction ratchet 43,52 to the screw 30, but requires a tool to be engaged with the drive recess 36 in order to loosen it. The ratchet includes teeth 43 on a ring 40, co-operating with a pawl 52 on a spring 50, also having a tab 51 engaging in notch 35 in flange 34 of the screw 30. Alternatively, the spring 50 may be coupled to the knob 20, not the screw 30. A helical spring 70 urges the knob 20 away from the ferrule 60 which is secured to the panel 80.

column12: Improvements in or relating to circular saws and their manufacture
column13: 935,714. Making circular saws; rolling. EDGAR ALLEN & CO. Ltd. Nov. 22, 1961 [April 8, 1961], No. 12726/61. Classes 83 (2) and 83 (4). [Also in Group XXIII] In the manufacture of a circular saw of the integral tooth type, a steel disc is heated progressively around its periphery, the metal is swaged into a space that increases in width towards the periphery of the disc, and the disc is cooled. The periphery of the motor-driven disc 1 is heated by oxygen and propane fed heaters 35B and passes between rolls 6B which are held in contact with and driven by the disc 1. A freely rotatable roll 26 acts on the edge of the disc to displace the periphery into a space formed by the chamfered edges 6AA and 6BB of rolls 6A and 6B. The disc and all three rolls are mounted on screw adjusted slides. The disc is cooled by water jets 53 and by further jets situated radially inwardly of the heater nozzles. The roll 26 may be cylindrical or barrel-shaped, or alternatively an impacting tool may be used to swage the disc. After swaging, equi-angled, double-angled, or single-angled teeth may be cut in the disc.

column12: Fahrzeugsitz mit Netzgewebe
column13: Die Erfindung betrifft einen Fahrzeugsitz mit Netzgewebe für ein Sonderfahrzeug. Der Fahrzeugsitz weist eine Auflage und eine Rückenlehne auf, die jeweils mit einem Textilgewebe umhüllt sind. Die Auflage umfaßt ein Sitzformteil und eine Bodenplatte, die miteinander befestigt sind, um das Textilgewebe des Sitzes auf der Auflage festzuhalten. Die Rückenlehne enthält einen Rückenlehnenrahmen, an dem ein vorderes Klemmenteil und ein hinteres Klemmenteil befestigt sind, um ein Rückenlehnen-Textilgewebe an der Rückenlehne festzuhalten. Eine konkave, untere Rückenlehnenhalterung ist vorgesehen, um der Rückenlehne des Sitzes in Verbindung mit den konkaven unteren Abschnitten der vorderen Klemme und der hinteren Klemme eine konkave Form zu verleihen. Der Sitz kann an einem einzelnen Untersatz oder einem doppelten Untersatz montiert sein.

column12: Dashboard rail and steering column support
column13: A dashboard attachment system for a specialty vehicle is described. A rail having first and second ribs located on front and rear edges thereof that are separated by a center portion of reduced thickness. A C-shaped mounting clip forms part of an accessory such as a bag hook, mirror, or cup holder that are secured by the C-shaped mounting clip to one of the ribs. A steering column support bracket including a C-shaped clip and a tubular receptacle for a steering column is provided. The rail is supported by rail supports that are anchored to the dashboard. The rail is finished by right and left end caps that have U-shaped rib interconnecting the first and second ribs on opposite lateral ends of the rail.

column12: Self-moving device, charging station, automatic working system, and insect suppression device thereof
column13: An insect suppression device, and further relates to a self-moving device, a charging station, and an automatic working system that are mounted with the insect suppression device are provided. The self-moving device moves in a working area, performs a working task, and includes: a body and a movement module that is mounted on the body and drives the self-moving device to move. The self-moving device includes: an insect suppression device, mounted to the body, and a control module, controlling the movement module to move and controlling the insect suppression device to work. The beneficial effects of the present invention are as follows: The self-moving device can move autonomously in the working area and perform an insect suppression task, and has a wide coverage area, flexible work, and high efficiency, so that automatic control can be implemented, thereby freeing a user from the harassment of insects.

column13: 959,567. Transformers and inductors; electric conductors; electric coils. REYNOLDS METALS CO. June 27, 1960, No. 22457/60. Headings H1A, H1P and H1T. [Also in Division H2] A conductor, which may be wound into a coil such as 10, for transformers, comprises layers of insulated and uninsulated strips, e.g. 13, 15, of aluminium and/or copper, such that the insulated strips are thin and can readily be coiled without cracking the insulation. The insulation 14, e.g. of aluminium oxide, may extend over one face, where the uninsulated strip 15 touches the uninsulated face, Fig. 2, or both faces, Fig. 4. In the first case the strips form a single conductor between terminals 11, 12 and in the second case they may form separate circuits. The bare strips are narrower but of greater section from the insulated ones, and the insulation 14 extends over the edges of strips 13 to prevent edge arcing. A coil with three separated conductors has a completely insulated strip 47, a half-insulated strip 48 and a bare strip 51. Multiplication of the uninsulated strips increases the area of the conductors for heavy duty. In this case, extra bare strips may contact the uninsulated face of the halfinsulated strip (Fig. 6a, not shown).

column12: COMPOSITION OF MATTER FOR COUGHS, ETC.
Chain saw attachment for unobstructed brush cutting
column13: The invention provides a chain saw attachment for unobstructed cutting of smaller objects with diameters less than three inches and larger objects with diameters greater than three inches. The attachment includes a set of prongs that vertically extend at an acute angle from a cover above the cutting teeth of the chain saw blade to a specified distance below the blade. The prongs stabilize small objects from whipping and dragging when engaged by the cutting teeth and facilitate the cutting of brush with diameter equal to height of the blade. Moreover, the cover does not extend the full length of the blade to allow for fully unobstructed cuts using the uncovered section of the blade. The cover increase safe operation of the chain saw and distributes stress from a particular prong over the entire attachment.

column12: Improved Apparatus for Cutting or Slitting and Reeling Paper
column13: 8862. Briggs, T. E., and Webb, E. April 30. Cutting-machines for paper.-The paper is drawn from a reel c, and wound by a friction drum d upon discs carried by a shaft or core h, and is simultaneously slit into suitable widths by a series of disc cutters upon a shaft i. The drum d is made in sections, of which only as many are brought into use as are required, adjustable guides g being fixed at the ends of the sections which are in use for holding the paper in position. The cutters n, separated by spacing-discs &c., are strung upon a shaft i, the bearings of which and also of the shaft h. are mounted to slide vertically in guides m as the winding of the cut strips continues. The axle i and cutters thereon are balanced by chains x and weights y, and are driven by chains r, one at each end of the machine, each chain being passed in the manner shown over guide-pulleys, of which one q<x> is weighted, and is capable of sliding vertically in guides j as the wound strips increase in diameter.

The seat may be provided on a single pedestal base or a double pedestal base.

column13: Disclosed is a thermoplastic polyolefin composition having improved adhesion to applied polymeric foams or coatings, the composition comprising (a) polypropylene, (b) a hydrogenated copolymer of a vinyl aromatic compound and an alkylene compound, comprising (i) from 1 to no more than 30% by weight of vinyl aromatic residues, based on the weight of the copolymer, and (ii) at least 55% by weight of alkylene residues that are C 4 or higher, based on total alkylene content of copolymer (b) prior to hydrogenation, (c) a functionalized polyolefin, and (d) a monoamine terminated polyalkylene oxide. In one embodiment, the functionalized polyolefin (c) and monoamine terminated polyalkylene oxide (d) form an adduct that is thermodynamically miscible with the copolymer (b) at adduct:copolymer (b) ratios of from 0.1:9.9 to 9.9:0.1.

Folded strip conductor for electrical coils and method of and apparatus for producing the same
column13: 906,831. Making electrical conductors. REYNOLDS METALS CO. Nov. 16, 1959, No. 38814/59. Class 83 (2). [Also in Groups XXXV and XXXVI] A flat-strip conductor, especially suitable for electrical coils, is formed by folding over the burred edges of a cut strip of metal to form rounded edges which, together with at least a part of the non-folded outer surface, are provided with an insulating covering. The preferred conductor comprises an aluminium foil strip with a coating formed by anodizing after folding, the coating extending around both edges and continuing across the unfolded outer surface. It may be formed by feeding the cut strip from a roll 30 through folding rolls 31 which fold the edges inwards and then through an ironing roll (not shown) which flattens the folded strip. It is then fed over guide roller 32 which directs it into tight engagement with an electrolytic roller 33 rotating in an electrolytic bath 34 containing e.g. a 15-18% aqueous solution of sulphuric acid. The roller 33 has a specially formed and partly masked surface (Fig. 7 and 8, not shown) so that only that part of the conductor which is to be anodized is in contact with the solution, and a plurality of suitably shaped cathodes 36 are provided. Suitable current densities and treatment times are given in the Specification. The strip then passes through a rinsing tank 51, a hot water sealing tank 52, and a pressurized-steam-sealing container 53, being finally fed by drive rolls 54 on to a storage spool 55.

column13: 780,038. Stuffing-box substitutes. METROPOLITAN-VICKERS ELECTRICAL CO., Ltd. Oct. 4, 1955 [Oct. 18, 1954], No. 29952/54. Class 122 (5). A labyrinth gland between relatively rotating members has one or both of the parts liable to rub against each other made of sintered metal. Suitable metals are sintered iron, sintered nickel, sintered nickel containing graphite, or sintered alloys, such as nickel-chromium, with or without graphite, and the sintering is preferably incomplete. column12: Housing with a gas-extraction device
column13: In a row of fume-extraction cabinets, each cabinet is closed by a door and is connected by an associated line to a common collecting line which, in turn, leads to an air-extraction fan. Within each line there is seated a rotatable throttle which is connected via a linkage to its associated door, so that when the door is closed, the line is progressively throttled to reduce the flow rate of air which is extracted from this fume-extraction cabinet. A potentiometer is connected such that it rotates together with the respective throttle and the signals generated are fed to a summing amplifier which varies the rotational speed of the extraction fan as a function of the number of open doors, in order to match the demand and performance of the air extraction system.

column12: Improvements in Switches or Cut-outs for Overhead Electric Wires.
column13: 3600. Ellis, A., and Smith, W. T. Feb. 23. Electric railways and tramways with safety appliances for overhead conductors. Conductors, supports for. Relates to means for connecting overhead conductors to earth in case of fracture. Fig. 5 shows one arrangement. The conductor is attached to an ear a supported on a pivot or slide so as to be capable of swinging to either side should the conductor break. The ear is fitted with switch contacts c, which are adapted to engage with a contact d in the hanger b in the event of breakage. The contact d is connected through the post or other support to earth or to the return conductor. Fig. 7 shows a modified construction, in which the ear a is connected by a link m to the hanger. In a further modification, the ear a is provided with guides which are adapted to slide in slots in a suitably-shaped hanger, and, in yet another arrangement, the hanger is fitted with contacts against which the ear itself strikes when swung over. The Provisional Specification describes an arrangement in which the conductor is in separate lengths, connected independently to the support, and, when one breaks, it is completely detached.

column12: Novel or Improved Machines or Apparatus for Use in Dipping Ceramic-ware, Glass-ware and like Ware into Glaze or Colour.
column13: 5673. Ellis, S. H., and Holt, T. March 27. Pottery ; enamelling.- A machine for dipping articles o f pottery o r glass in glaze or colour is constructed with a trough c, central shaft e, loose bushes a, radial spindles g, and cages for holding the articles. The cages containing the articles to be coated are turned down into the trough c by a handle d, fixed to the bush a, and are rotated in the liquid glaze o r colour b y a handle and bevel-wheelsf. Rotation of the cages about the shaft e is limited by stops projecting from the trough and a front table v. The table is constructed of four vertical bars 1, which are formed with lugs 2 for supporting plates or articles, and are connected by end rings 3. One bar is connected to the adjacent bar by pivoted arms, and is secured between the rings by sliding bolts forced outwards by springs. Radial arms of the lower ring 3 fit in undercut radial recesses in a head or table at the end of the spindle g, and are secured in place by a spring lever or catch. Conical hoods protect the wheels and bearings from the liquid glaze, and a quadrantal hood p over the trough is fitted with doors q closed by springs s. In a modification, a vertical support is fitted with adjustable sliding heads which are formed with projections adapted to hold ewers in position. For supporting basins, the bars 1 are notched to receive rings formed with radial ribs or supports. In each of these modifications, one vertical bar is pivoted to the lower ring and secured to the upper ring by a pivoted spring catch.

column12: UN METODO Y UN SISTEMA PARA UTILIZAR UNA GUIA DE PROGRAMACION TELEVISIVA INTERACTIVA
column13: La presente consiste en un método para utilizar una guía de programacion televisiva interactiva para grabar programas, que comprende: recibir una primera seleccion hecha utilizando la guía de programacion televisiva interactiva para grabar un primer programa televisivo en un dispositivo de almacenamiento digital con acceso aleatorio; dirigir un primer sintonizador para sintonizar un canal correspondiente al primer programa de television como respuesta a la recepcion de la primer seleccion del usuario; grabar la salida del primer sintonizador en el dispositivo de almacenamiento digital de acceso aleatorio; recibir una segunda seleccion del usuario realizada usando la guía de programacion televisiva interactiva para grabar un segundo programa de television en el dispositivo de almacenamiento digital de acceso aleatorio, donde el tiempo de transmision del segundo programa de television se superpone, al menos parcialmente, con el tiempo de transmision del primer programa de television; dirigir un segundo sintonizador para sintonizar el canal correspondiente al segundo programa de television como respuesta a la recepcion de la segunda seleccion del usuario; y grabar simultáneamente la salida del segundo sintonizador junto con la salida del primer sintonizador en el dispositivo de almacenamiento digital de acceso aleatorio.

APPARATUS AND METHOD FOR MULTI-STATE CODE SIGNING
column13: An electronic device includes a memory configured to store a lab certificate, a code authentication certificate and the executable code. The electronic device also includes a processor associated with a unique device identifier. For a first operational condition of the plurality of operational conditions, the processor is configured to: retrieve the code authentication certificate associated with the executable code; determine that a valid lab certificate is present in the memory; authenticate the code authentication certificate by determining that the code authentication certificate is signed with a private developer key and that the signature is valid; and execute the executable code on the electronic device responsive to determining that the lab certificate is valid and authenticating the code authentication certificate.

column12: Three-dimensional imaging by projecting morphologically filtered pixel data
column13: In three-dimensional imaging of ultrasound data, speckle artifact data are reduced before the acquired data from a volume of interest are projected onto an image plane. A master controller performs an algorithm that iteratively morphologically filters (28) the pixel data in a volume of interest and then iteratively projects (30,32,34) the morphologically filtered data onto a plurality of rotated image planes using a ray-casting technique. Morphological filtering is performed by stepping a seven-point kernel through a source data volume of pixel data. The kernel, made up of a central pixel value and the six pixel values adjacent to the central pixel value, is stepped through the entire source data volume. The morphological filtering operation includes at least one erosion step, which removes speckle, followed by an equal number of dilation steps, which restore the imaging data.

Three-dimensional imaging by projecting morphologically filtered pixel data
column13: In three-dimensional imaging of ultrasound data, speckle artifact data are reduced before the acquired data from a volume of interest are projected onto an image plane. A master controller performs an algorithm that iteratively morphologically filters the pixel data in a volume of interest and then iteratively projects the morphologically filtered data onto a plurality of rotated image planes using a ray-casting technique. Morphological filtering is performed by stepping a seven-point kernel through a source data volume of pixel data. The kernel, made up of a central pixel value and the six pixel values adjacent to the central pixel value, is stepped through the entire source data volume. The morphological filtering operation includes at least one erosion step, which removes speckle, followed by an equal number of dilation steps, which restore the imaging data.

column12: One-direction captive screw fastener
column13: A one-directional captive screw attachable to a panel that is hand tightenable, but requires a tool to loosen once hand tightened. The captive screw includes a screw having a head with a recess and a threaded portion, a knob having a central longitudinal axis coaxial with the screw, a one-directional ratchet between the knob and the screw. The ratchet engages to allow the screw to be tightened in a clockwise direction using the knob, and disengages when rotated in a counterclockwise direction, such that a tool is required to loosen the screw by use of the recess.

column12: Apparatuses and methods for surgical navigation
column13: Imaging, object tracking, integration apparatus 100 has tracking system 1, imaging system 3, communication system 5 and integration system 7. Tracking system 1 locates objects in 3-dimensions and determines respective poses. Imaging system 3 acquires object images. Integration system 7 correlates 3-dimensional poses. User communication system 5 provides information, such as images, sounds, or control signals to the user or other automated systems. Image acquisition techniques include X-ray imaging and ultrasound imaging. Images can be acquired from digital files. Imaging system 3 creates a calibrated, geometrically corrected two-dimensional image 110, 210 . Correlation system 7 can receive instructions from a practitioner to create, destroy, and edit the properties of a guard. Communications system 5 displays images and calculations to a practitioner, such as a surgeon. Methods can determine geometrical relations between guards and/or present to a practitioner projections of forms of guards.

SYSTEM FOR TREATING PROSTATE GRAND AND METHOD FOR TREATING PROSTATE GRAND SURROUNDING URETHRA
column13: PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide a system for treating a prostate grand and a method for treating a prostate grand surrounding urethra, which can offer a safe, quick, and inexpensive treatment against benign prostatic disease. SOLUTION: A system 20 for treating a prostate grand is provided with an acoustic carrier 22, a phase Fresnel band 24 in a region of the acoustic carrier 22, and an acoustic transducer 26. The phase Fresnel band 24 is formed at the acoustic carrier 22 next to the first end 28 of the acoustic carrier 22 as well as at least partially extends the circumference of an outer surface 32 of the acoustic carrier 22. The acoustic transducer 26 is connected to the second end 30 of the acoustic carrier 22. To treat a prostate grand, the acoustic carrier 22 is inserted and positioned to the urethra so that the phase Fresnel band 24 is positioned at the area of the urethra surrounded by the prostate grand. The acoustic wave is sent to the second end 30 so that the phase Fresnel band 24 is focused to make the acoustic wave interfere at a position of the prostate grand in a structural way.

System and method for treatment of a prostate with a phase fresnel probe
column13: A system for treating a prostate includes an acoustic carrier, a phase fresnel zone in a section of the acoustic carrier, and an acoustic transducer. The phase fresnel zone is formed in the acoustic carrier adjacent a first end of the acoustic carrier and extends at least partially around the outer surface of the acoustic carrier. An acoustic transducer is coupled to a second end of the acoustic carrier. In treating the prostate, which surrounds a urethra, the acoustic carrier is inserted into the urethra and positioned so that the phase fresnel zone is situated in a region of the urethra surrounded by the prostate. Acoustic waves are transmitted into the second end of the acoustic carrier and the phase fresnel zone focuses the acoustic waves to constructively interfere at the location in the prostate. By moving the acoustic carrier, the phase fresnel zone may be moved along at least a portion of the region of the urethra surrounded by the prostate while the acoustic waves are being transmitted.

Polymer encapsulated electrical devices
column13: Improved encapsulated, overmolded and/or underfilled electrical components having a complete encapsulation, overmolding and/or underfilling with a coefficient of thermal expansion that is uniform and substantially free of gradients includes a polymeric matrix and an inorganic filler having a platelet geometric structure. The platelet structure of the filler allows a desirable coefficient of thermal expansion to be achieved using a very low level of filler material. This low level of filler material facilitates lower viscosity during forming of the encapsulation and/or overmolding, thereby facilitating complete filling of a mold cavity and underfilling of space between a circuit board and a semi-conductor chip electrically connected to the circuit board. In addition, the low viscosity has processing advantages that reduce the potential for damage to electrical components during encapsulation, overmolding and/or underfilling.

column13: PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To obtain a structure capable of giving visual contrast useful for proof reading and useful as a lithographic printing plate having hydrophilic property and durability. SOLUTION: This structure useful as a lithographic printing plate contains an inorg. metallic layer 12 having both hydrophilic property and practical durability even in the case of a very thin layer. The metallic layer 12 is ablated when it absorbs imaging radiation and direct imaging is facilitated without carrying out chemical development. The metallic layer 12 is also useful to form an optical interference structure 18 and this structure 18 develops a color and is ablated in response to an imaging pulse when it absorbs imaging radiation.

column12: CONICAL BEARING ASSEMBLIES
column13: 1,203,393. Moulding conical bearings. MINISTER OF TECHNOLOGY. 18 March, 1969 [26 March, 1968], No. 14588/68. Heading B5A. [Also in Division F2] Bearing members having frusto-conical surfaces are made by machining a bearing surface on one of the members, casting bearing material against the surface to form a bearing surface which adheres to a second bearing member and separating the members. The machined bearing surface may be treated to prevent the bearing material adhering to it. A frustoconical male member 10 having an accurately machined surface 14 is mounted on a shaft 12 on which is coaxially mounted a female member 11 having a conical recess 15, there being a P.T.F.E. bush 13 disposed between the shaft and the female member. The surface 14 of member 10 is coated with silicon wax and a resin 19 is poured into the conical recess. The male member is moved along the shaft in the direction A causing the resin to fill the space between the members. The thickness of the layer of bearing material is determined by the end face 16 of the member 10 abutting the bush 13. A sleeve 17 is slid along the outside of the female member to shear off any excess resin, and engages with the flange 18 of the male member to align the bearing members. After the resin has set the male member is removed, the bush 13 replaced by a spacer 22 and the male member is replaced on the shaft, the bearing clearance being determined by the length of the spacer. The resin may be an epoxy resin which may contain aluminium oxide and carbon fibres. The cast bearing surface may be provided with grooves, in which fluid may be pressurized during operation of the bearing, by casting the bearing material between the female member and a member identical with the male member except that it has on its surface a raised pattern corresponding to that of the groove pattern required, this member being replaced, after the material has set, by a member having a smooth surface.

column13: Tornillo de fijación cautivo, unidireccional. Un tornillo cautivo unidireccional acoplable a un panel que se puede apretar a mano, pero que requiere una herramienta para aflojarlo una vez apretado a mano. El tornillo cautivo comprende un tornillo que tiene una cabeza dotada de un rebaje y una zona roscada, un botón o cabeza que tiene un eje longitudinal central coaxial con el tornillo, una rueda de trinquete monodireccional entre dicho botón y cabeza y el tornillo. La rueda de trinquete se acopla permitiendo que el tornillo se pueda apretar en la dirección de las agujas del reloj, utilizando dicho botón y se desacopla cuando se hace girar en dirección contraria de las agujas del reloj, de manera que se requiere una herramienta para aflojar el tornillo por utilización de dicho rebaje.

column12: Method and apparatus for making strip conductor coils and the like with terminal leads attached thereto
column13: 1,072,078. Making coils, welding by pressure, shearing and perforating. REYNOLDS METALS CO. Oct. 20, 1965, No. 44489/65 Headings B3A, B3R and B3W. A strip conductor coil 30 is wound from conductive strip 31 and insulating strip 39 on an insulating core 32. The supply rolls 40, 41 are mounted on free wheeling rollers 44, 45 respectively and the strips pass over turning bars 46, 47 respectively. Each roller is fitted with an adjustable spring-loaded brake (201), (202), (203) (Fig. 4, not shown) which are connected to lever arms (48), (49) loaded by adjustable springs 52, 53, respectively and on which are respectively mounted the bars 46, 47. A mandrel 63 is advanced by a fluid pressureoperated piston-rod 64 into a retainer 96 of a hopper 70 where it picks up a core 32. The mandrel is withdrawn and rotated to the station 67 whereupon it is again advanced, a clutch member (81) (Fig. 18, not shown) on the mandrel engaging a mating clutch member (82) on the end of a drive shaft 60. A taping head 139 holds the strips 31, 39 together on a table (138) (Fig. 24, not shown) and applies a length of adhesive tape (141) to the strip (31) and to the core (32) (Fig. 25, not shown). The shaft 60 is rotated to wind the coil and when almost fully wound is stopped. Two parallel strips of contact material 103 are advanced by members 109 so as transversely to overlie the strip 31 to form leading and trailing contacts (33), (34) respectively. The underneath of the strips 103 is cleaned by brushes 119. A die block 57 is lowered driving a rod 123 downwardly until it abuts a block 131 whereupon projections 134 cold weld the contact strip to the strip 31. Simultaneously a member 135 perforates the strip between the contacts (Fig. 2, not shown). The strips are further advanced until the trailing contact (34) is under the taping head 139, which is then lowered to hold the strips against the table 138 (Fig. 21, not shown). A second taping head 140 is lowered on to the coil to apply a tape thereto and the shaft 60 is again rotated so that the strip is ruptured at the perforations. The mandrel 63 is moved to the station 68, where its resistance is checked and if it is unsatisfactory it is removed from the mandrel by a stripping mechanism 72. If the coil complies with the test it is removed from the mandrel at station 69 by a stripping mechanism 73, where it falls into a hopper.
